Snifles the 
 crocodile and
 
 Punch the buterfly
 Herminder Ohri
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the swamp on the far side of the Far Forest, lived Snifles, the crocodile.
 Snifles was always crying big crocodile tears or going snif.snif. Even his
 
 mom was quite tired of him and would say, "Stop sniveling and crying, start
 behaving like a crocodile. Go hunt for your fod." But Snifles would burst
 into tears at the thought of eating another animal. So mom and dad had to
 
 fed Snifles every day. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Snifles did not want to be a crocodile. "I am so ugly," he thought, bursting
 into tears. He did not even want to live like crocodiles do. His best friend
 
 was Punch, a golden yelow buterfly. And Punch wanted to be big and
 strong. So Punch always had her feler curled into a fist saying, "Lok out! I
 wil punch you in the mouth." 
 
 
 They made a very funy pair. Snifles swiming with Punch perched on his
 
 head. The other crocodiles would laugh and make fun of them. That did not
 bother Snifles. He continued crying, snifling and being friends with Punch.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 One suny afternon, Punch setled herself near Snifles' ear and told him, "I
 have sen two men come this way with guns, they want to kil crocodiles for
 
 their skins." 
 
 
 "Don't these men have skins of their own?" asked a puzled Snifles.
 
 "I don't know Snifles." replied Punch. "Tel the other crocodiles and hide."
 
 
 "But Punch, they might shot you. Oh! What wil I do?" cried Snifles sobing
 
 loudly. 
 
 "People catch buterflies with nets and pin them on a board, my grandaunt
 
 told me," said Punch and flew away. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The other crocodiles heard Snifles crying and shouting, "Men coming to kil
 us. Hide.Hury.Hide." At first the crocodiles did not believe Snifles, but
 then they heard the men's fotsteps. 
 
 
 The crocodiles went dep into the river and left some roten logs floating on
 the water. The men shot at the logs which loked like crocodiles from afar.
 
 The men could not se any crocodiles, only hundreds of buterflies that flew
 into their faces and hair. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Shaking their heads and trying to brush of the buterflies 
 they said, "There are no crocodiles here, we wil bring nets 
 
 and catch the buterflies." And of they went. Al the 
 crocodiles got together and said, 
 "Thank you, Punch." 
 
 "Thank you, buterflies." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day Snifles saw men with nets. He remembered
 Punch teling him about nets. 
 
 
 "Punch, the nets! Come here quick! The men with the nets
 have come." 
 
 
 Al the crocodiles came on the river bank. The buterflies
 setled on the backs and heads of the crocodiles.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A few of the crocodiles made a circle around the men as they came close.
 
 The crocodiles snaped their jaws. Snifles was in front, gnashing his teth
 and whiping his tail around most menacingly. The men were so frightened
 that they tok to their hels and ran right out of the swamp. 
 
 
 The other crocodiles were very proud of Snifles, as he had acted like a real
 
 crocodile. Now Snifles was also proud to be one.

 Al the buterflies flew around the crocodiles, flutering their wings.
 
 
 "Thank you, Snifles, thank you, crocodiles." 
 
 
 "It is alright," said Snifles shyly. 
 
 
 "That is what friends are for, to take care of each other."
